Message.Title: Throwing the baby out with the bath water- the IBM way
Message.Msg: Tossing out IBM R&D staff in pretty large numbers just in order to secure rosy next quarter financials for the bigwigs in management, and preserve their (rather large) bonuses seems very much like throwing the baby out with the bath water. It is a myopic, short sighted management policy, aimed at providing shareholders only short term gains, but does not necessarily bode well for the company's long-term future There have been substantial job cuts in the R&D centers, semiconductor development and software development sectors at IBM; those impacted by the "resource action" are the very folks who were developing tomorrow's great technologies at IBM. These researchers will now be snapped up by the competition, and develop innovative products and services at their new corporations which could have been IBM's future, and now won't be. These folks have been cut rather than the dead weight middle and upper management who through crony-ism seem to hold on to their jobs at Armonk, and elsewhere within IBM, at each job cut cycle. It is the staff under these people who do all the work for these multi-layers of VPs and SVPs; they themselves just delegate, and may not be cognizant of the inner workings of all the cogwheels in their organization. It is the general staff who holds the client lists, interact with clients and determine the clients' needs and wants, and when these worker bees' jobs are eliminated, the knowledge base and history is all lost, and senior management now left holding the empty bag is all discombobulated in the organizational wilderness. Cutting off your own legs from under you is not the best business model. Once the corporation's baby floats away with the tossed bath water it is lost forever, and with it quite possibly the future potential products and services- the very genetic code for the company's survival and evolution is lost forever. All in the name of the next quarter's financials to be presented to Wall Street.
